body: When the Oceanfront Development Corporation, a local community organization in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, sought help to upgrade the Neptune Avenue commercial district last year, it contacted the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the voluntary charitable agency. The federation responded by helping the community group
title: CHARITABLE GROUP FIGHTS CITY DECAY

body: A bookmaking operation that is believed to have been mob-connected and to have handled more than $25 million a year in illegal sports bets was broken up Monday night with police raids on six of the ring's facilities in three New York City boroughs, the authorities said yesterday. Ten people at the facilities - so-called wire rooms, where bets were
title: BOOKMAKING RING BROKEN UP; POLICE LINK IT TO CRIME FAMILY

body: ''ZAICHIK,'' said Igor Sverellin, nudging a companion in the ribs and pointing. ''Zaichik.'' The word is Russian for ''little rabbit,'' and Mr. Sverellin, one of a group of 49 Russian immigrants having a guided evening out at the Playboy Club in Manhattan, was demonstrating by pointing at Bunny Robin and Bunny Cynthia that he knew a real zaichik
title: NIGHT ON THE TOWN FOR SOVIET IMMIGRANTS

title: SPOT BUILDER IS TREADING WATER

body: A jewelry salesman on his way to work yesterday was robbed of $60,000 in gold and $1,500 in cash by two men who forced their way into his car when he stopped for a traffic light in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, the police said. The victim was Alex Slomovigs, 28 years old, of Brooklyn. The police, who did not give out his home address,
title: THE CITY; 2 Rob Salesman Of $60,000 in Gold

body: JERRY WURF Labor's Last Angry Man. By Joseph C. Goulden. Illustrated. 296 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95. JERRY WURF was one of the most remarkable union men of this century. Born in New York City in 1919 to immigrant parents from Austria and Hungary, he was stricken with polio when he was 4 years old, spent much of his youth in a wheelchair and
title: A LEADER FOR THE LITTLE GUY

body: Brighton Beach, long overshadowed by its more rambunctious neighbor, Coney Island, is having a street fair Sunday to show its stuff. There will be food, carnival rides, music, antiques, clothing and Brighton's great natural resource, the beach. The event, known as the Brighton Jubilee, will take place from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. along a six-block
title: AT BRIGHTON BEACH, A STREET FAIR HAS THE TANG OF THE SEA

body: A Brighton Beach Party I t has been called the Subway Riviera - a Brooklyn beach club that had 12,000 members at its peak and still has more than 6,000, ''aged 6 months to 90 years.'' So yesterday, for the 75th anniversary of the Brighton Beach Baths, 8,000 members and guests jammed parking lots or rode the IND or BMT to the end of the line. In hot
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: THE AQUARIUM If it were set any other place in the country, it would be the major attraction of the area and people would drive hundreds of miles to visit it. But in this city the New York Aquarium, near the boardwalk in Coney Island, on Surf Avenue at West Eighth Street (266-8500), seems far away and is likely to be overlooked. It is a pity,
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: A New York State appellate court yesterday voided the guilty plea of a Brooklyn dentist who admitted to sexually abusing an investigator posing as a patient. The court held that a videotape camera surreptiously installed in the ceiling of the dentist's office - and that had recorded the sexual abuse of the woman - had been put into place too long
title: A DENTIST'S PLEA OF GUILT VOIDED IN SEXUAL ABUSE

body: Back to Brooklyn, Where a Career Began S he graduated from Brooklyn's James Madison High School with an NBC contract in her pocket and went on to an international operatic and show-business career. But Elaine Malbin, quick to say ''I was a plain little old Brooklyn girl,'' was back last night at Midwood Field - near the Flatbush home of her
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Four Concerts Planned By Brooklyn Philharmonic Music continues to blossom in Brooklyn's parks with four pops concerts Wednesday through Sunday with the Brooklyn Philharmonic conducted by Bruce Ferden. Featuring music from the operatic repertory designed to lift limp spirits, Mr. Ferden will conduct the soprano Elaine Malbin in arias by Puccini,
title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS

body: The New York City Health Department has released the names of 17 food establishments it said had violated the Health Code. The department also released the names of two establishments that reopened after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for failure to do so. The establishments are: VIOLATIONS Govas Restaurant, 94 1/2 Greenwich
title: 17 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED FOR VIOLATIONS OF HEALTH CODE

body: Accessible by subway or bus, 15 miles of city beaches line the shores of four of the boroughs - all except Manhattan. The beaches, maintained by the city, are free, clean and, now that the freeze on hiring municipal employees has been lifted, fully staffed with lifeguards. ''The beaches can be reached by public transportation - that is their
title: NEW YORK CITY BEACHES: FREE AND EASY TO REACH

body: ABOUT nine years ago, when he was working on ''The Sunshine Boys,'' Neil Simon began to think about a play that would deal with people coping with the Depression and facing World War II. Five years later, he got around to starting such a play, but he put it aside after he found himself unable to write more than 35 pages. Last year the play suddenly
title: BROADWAY; Brighton Beach in 1938 is setting for Simon play.

body: Not long after becoming head of Queens College in 1971, Joseph S. Murphy was invited to a Sholom Aleichem festival being held on campus. Those attending the gathering in memory of the Yiddish writer quickly learned how adept the young college president could be in charming an audience. He spoke in Yiddish. Whether conversing in English, Yiddish,
title: MAN IN THE NEWS; A BRIDGE BUILDER FOR CITY UNIVERSITY

body: On a sunny May morning in 1953, my wife and I and our two daughters moved from a three-room apartment into our own home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. In terms of distance the move was simple and swift - no more than a quarter of a mile from where we had lived. In terms of comfort, life style, costs and the many responsibilities that go with
title: AFTER RETIREMENT, WE CHOSE TO STAY IN FLATBUSH

body: In a short story called ''Only the Dead Know Brooklyn,'' Thomas Wolfe looked down his nose at the long blocks of two-family houses and wondered how any individual thought could develop in such a uniform atmosphere. Whatever Wolfe may have imagined, a great deal of creativity has come out of Brooklyn's neighborhoods over the years. Additional proof
title: LIBRARY CAMPAIGN EVOKES FONDNESS

body: More than a year ago, Abraham Newman risked his life to aid a woman in trouble. He has been paying for it ever since. Mr. Newman, then 83 years old, was walking on the boardwalk at Brighton Beach in Brooklyn on Oct. 16, 1980, when he tried to help a woman who was being assaulted by a young man. The assailant grabbed Mr. Newman's cane, beat him and
title: MAN, 83, WHO HELPED CRIME VICTIM IS REFUSED MONETARY AWARD BY CITY

body: Representative Stephen J. Solarz was in Cleveland the other day delivering a fervent address on the security and survival of Israel. As he drew to a close, Mr. Solarz, who speaks in a manner that is both confident and affable, came to the matter closest to his heart and the real reason he had flown more than 1,000 miles for a two-hour visit. ''Like
title: SOLARZ PLANS FOR A RACE TO KEEP BROOKLYN SEAT

body: The waiting room was narrow, stuffy and crammed with wriggling boys and girls - a mass of yellow curls, black pigtails, bangs, barrettes, hairbows, ruffles, jeans, velveteen, long lashes, cowlicks, newly gap-toothed smiles and freckles. They were reticent or assertive, from New Jersey and Long Island and Connecticut as well as New York City, with
title: 'STILL MISSING': A CALL FOR CHILDREN
